Topic.Title: Anand Chandrasekher quit INTC and joined QCOM

Message.Msg: This happened after the Nokia debacle. Anand was excessively focused on this mega deal with Nokia on coming out with Meego-based phones - which was a strategic error. When Nokia decided to drop it and go with Windows Phone, Intel was left in the lurch. It was a pretty bad black eye for Intel...leaving Paul Otellini no option but to let Anand go. Lesson learned, Intel has been working with multiple players on its phone platform since then - and announced Lava, Lenovo, Motorola, Orange, ZTE, etc.

Message.Title: Goldman Sachs raises US semiconductor sector to attractive
Message.Msg: Goldman: everyone does great except Intel. GS James Covello continues to be fixated and wrong about Intel margins. Aug 7 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs upgraded the U.S. semiconductor sector to "attractive," citing healthy supply and attractive valuations and raised its rating on Freescale Semiconductor Holdings Ltd , Applied Materials Inc and LSI to "buy". Semiconductor unit shipments have been 10 to 20 percent below normalized demand since the fourth quarter of 2011, resulting in healthy supply levels at customers, Goldman analysts wrote in a note to clients. The brokerage expects lean supply to mitigate lower near-term demand and eventually drive a strong cyclical recovery. Goldman downgraded Atmel Corp to "neutral" from "buy," citing weaker-than-expected demand for its smartphone touch controllers. It retained chipmakers Altera Corp and NXP Semiconductors NV as its top picks after beat-and-raise quarters. The brokerage also said it continues to expects margin weakness at Intel Corp and Advanced Micro Devices due to excess supply. "We believe Intel's orders could decline as it has record inventory," the brokerage said. https://research.tdwaterhouse.ca/research/public/Markets/NewsArticle/1314-L6E8J20XY-1

Message.Title: Intel-powered smart phones to be released within a month - in Russia
Message.Msg: Before you say it is an old article, Russia, unlike the US, uses DD/MM/YYYY. ========================== Intel-powered smart phones to be released within a month by Nathan Toohey at 06/08/2012 18:59 The recently announced Intel processor-based smart phones will be appearing in Russia over the course of the next month, RIA Novosti reported on Monday, citing an announcement from mobile provider Megafon, which will be distributing the devices. “The first device will be presented in the upcoming month. Information on pricing and technical characteristics of the device is to be announced later,” RIA Novosti quoted Yulia Dorokhina, Megafon’s press secretary, as saying on Monday. Fighting to win market share Intel confirmed that it was planning to release a smart phone featuring its processors on the local market in an effort to win back the mobile devices market, which was largely held by rival processors ARM. Devices based on the Intel Atom processor have already been released in India and Britain. The Intel-powered smart phones all run on the Android operating system. Under 20,000 rubles Earlier, Intel’s regional director for Russia, Dmitry Konash, said that the company was holding talks with all of the major mobile providers over distributing its products. He said that operator-provided Intel smart phones could be sold for less than 20,000 rubles even before any mobile provider subsidies were taken into consideration. The Lava XOLO X900, which runs on the Intel Atom (Medfield) processor and sports a 4-inch display, 8-megapixel camera and 16 GB of memory, recently went on sale in India for approximately $400, while the Intel-powered LePhone K800 with a 4.5-inch display, 8-megapixel camera and 16 GB of memory, just appeared on the market in China for a little over $500. http://themoscownews.com/business/20120806/190045995.html

Topic.Title: Intel-powered smart phones to be released within a month - in Russia

Message.Msg: Russia makes sense for Intel's phones becuase unlike the U.S. market where most people pay exhorbitant prices for smartphones through hidden subsidies and contracts, Russians are accustomed to paying upfront to own their own phones. People who pay cash upfront for their phones are more aware of cost and look for better value.

Message.Title: The Key Question Is - Can Intel Get To ARM Cost Of Production Or Lower?
Message.Msg: Key Questions for Intel Take-Off: (1) Intel Executive Mike Bell has remarked that his boss Paul Otellini told him that they are not going to lose any deal due to price. So cost of production (which impacts margins) is critical for Intel continuing to deliver good results. When will Intel reach cost-parity with ARM-based vendors? Are they already there? Or, will they reach such parity at 22nm or 14nm? Once Intel reaches cost-parity or lower cost than ARM vendors, the ARM camp has to compete more aggressively to win business. I wouldn't want to be in their shoes at that time. (2) Intel Smartphones Running Android 4.1 Jelly Bean: Intel Medfield runs Gingerbread, Jelly Bean shoud be here soon (MIPS Karbonn phone has been introduced running 4.1 Jelly Bean, Intel can't be far behind). (3) Intel Tablets running Android 4.1 Jelly Bean: No Android-based Tablets yet, hopefully the same 4.1 Jelly Bean compatibility is what they are waiting on...if so, again, they can't be far behind. (4) Performance/Battery: Intel-based phones have been introduced showing they can compare well with current devices. New Atoms featuring dual cores for Tablets is key to show better performance vis-a-vis Tegra/Snapdragon/Exynos. When will these new Atoms come out?

Topic.Title: The Key Question Is - Can Intel Get To ARM Cost Of Production Or Lower?

Message.Msg: There was a small company in Los Angeles that was selling the plastic bags used in grocery stores. They were a thorn in the side of their largest competitor. When this competitor had enough they went into the small company's largest two accounts and gave them a price below the small company's cost. The large company was known as Exxon Mobile. The small company is gone and the two years are up and today Mobile gets their price. What you will see next year is consolidation. Samsung, Apple and Qualcom will survive, I am not so certain about the rest. I love how D.A.N. tells stories about TSMC's flying through 28nm to 20nm. Nobody can inflict as much pain and damage in the industry as Intel. If Intel wasn't such a big threat he wouldn't waste his time thinking about Intel. Sooner or later Intel will fill capacity, get their price and their margin. And they will go 'Exxon' on any company that dares stand in their way.

Topic.Title: Intel Insider Selling

Message.Msg: Who do you think sold at a loss and why do you think that? I bet you are looking at the RSU vesting cost basis. RSU stock options cost him $0.00. The cost basis is set to market price when the RSU units vest. Some of the RSU units are typically sold automatically to pay the taxes and adjust the cost basis. When he sells at a "loss", he gets the taxes back that he just paid when they vested. Isn't that a $1 loss on a $26 profit? I would like that problem every day: a $25 profit on 150,000 shares. Nice!

Message.Title: 7” x 1.35” x 7.1”
Message.Msg: [An Ivy Bridge desktop in a small form factor starting at $639. Anyone who thinks that the proliferation of big performance in a small package isn't going to affect tablet sales is nuts...] [Note to Wall Street: Intel doesn't sell PCs. Intel sells processors. You nitwits...] Businesses are one of the last bastions of the desktop PC. Laptops and all-in-ones have infiltrated offices just as they have everywhere else, but enterprises are still buying plenty of PC towers from the likes of HP, Dell, and Lenovo. That doesn't mean that these towers have to be boring. While Micro ATX desktops are still the norm, the advancements in technology that have allowed for thinner and more powerful laptops can be used to make a business desktop that takes up less space without giving up the power and repairability so important for businesses. Lenovo's ThinkCentre M92p isn't the first tiny desktop on the market by any means, but it brings Ivy Bridge processors, triple monitor support, USB 3.0, and management and security features that businesses like in a package that won't take up much space on your desk. http://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2012/08/review-ivy-bridge-brings-big-performance-to-tiny-lenovo-thinkcentre-m92p/
